sens.mc: being about midway between extremes of amount or size
sens.vi: for the state of Florida, what is the mean number of sunny days per month?
sens.syn: average, intermediate, mean, median, medium, middling, midsize (also midsized), moderate, modest
sens.rel: reasonable; common, commonplace, conventional, normal, popular, regular, routine, standard, typical, usual; adequate, passable, tolerable
sens.near: excessive, extreme; exceptional, rare, strange, uncommon, unusual; distinctive, idiosyncratic, special, unique; individual, peculiar, private

sens.mc: belonging to the class of people of low social or economic rank
sens.vi: Alexander Hamilton seems to have had feelings of inferiority because of his mean origins
sens.syn: baseborn, common, humble, inferior, low, lowborn, lower-class, low-life, lowly, lumpen, mean, plebeian, prole, proletarian, unwashed, vulgar
sens.rel: bourgeois, middle-class; plain, poor, simple, working-class; déclassé, down-market, downscale
sens.ant: aristocratic, blue-blooded, genteel, gentle, grand, great, high, highborn, highbred, lofty, noble, partrician, upper-class, upper-crust, wellborn

sens.mc: giving or sharing as little as possible
sens.vi: a mean child who hoarded all her toys
sens.syn: cheap, chintzy, close, closefisted, mean, mingy, miserly, niggard, niggardly, parsimonious, penny-pinching, penurious, pinching, pinchpenny, spare, sparing, stinting, tight, tightfisted, uncharitable, ungenerous

sens.near: altruistic, selfless, unselfish; extravagant, free, handsome, lavish, overgenerous, profuse; beneficent, benevolent, hospitable, humanitarian, philanthropic (also philanthropical); compassionate, good-hearted, greathearted, kindly, magnanimous, openhearted; thriftless, unthrifty; dissipating, frittering, prodigal, profligate, spendthrift, splurging, squandering, wasteful, wasting
sens.ant: bounteous, bountiful, charitable, freehanded, generous, liberal, munificent, openhanded, unsparing, unstinting

sens.mc: having or showing a desire to cause someone pain or suffering for the sheer enjoyment of it
sens.vi: a mean, embittered old woman who wanted company for her misery
sens.syn: bad [slang], bitchy, catty, cruel, despiteful, malevolent, malicious, malign, malignant, mean, nasty, spiteful, vicious, virulent
sens.rel: devious, scoundrelly, scurvy, snakelike; acrimonious, bitter, envious, jaundiced, jealous, rancorous, resentful, vindictive, vitriolic; contemptuous, deprecating, derogatory, disdainful, disparaging, mean-spirited, obnoxious, opprobrious, scornful, snide, snotty, unkind, unkindly, unloving; baleful, baneful, evil; harsh, hostile, inimical; acrid, caustic, poisonous, scathing, venomous
sens.near: compassionate, good, good-hearted, kind, kindhearted, kindly, sympathetic, warm, warmhearted; affable, agreeable, amiable, cordial, friendly, genial, gracious, nice, pleasant; affectionate, amorous, sweet, tender, tenderhearted; humane; altruistic, high-minded, humanitarian, magnanimous, noble, philanthropic (also philanthropical)

sens.mc: not following or in accordance with standards of honor and decency
sens.vi: a mean trick to play on a trusting person

sens.ant: high, high-minded, honorable, lofty, noble, straight, upright, venerable, virtuous

sens.mc: of little or less value or merit
sens.vi: it's no mean feat to memorize that long poem

sens.near: major, more, primary, senior; choice, exceptional, first-class, first-rate, high-grade, premium, prime, select, selected; acceptable, adequate, sufficient

sens.vi: I'm a mean dancer, so you could do worse than go to the prom with me

sens.mc: showing signs of advanced wear and tear and neglect
sens.vi: he worked hard to escape the mean neighborhood of his youth

sens.near: brand-new, fresh, new; cared-for, kept-up, maintained; mended, patched, rebuilt, reconstructed; smart, spiffy, spruce

sens.mc: arousing or deserving of one's loathing and disgust
sens.vi: that was no mean stunt to pull off, especially with so little advance preparation

sens.ant: admirable, commendable, creditable, laudable, meritorious, praiseworthy

sens.vi: that candidate's moderate views were seen as the mean that voters were looking for
sens.syn: golden mean, medium, middle, middle ground, midpoint

sens.mc: to communicate or convey (as an idea) to the mind
sens.vi: the national anthem means various things to various people
sens.syn: denote, express, import, intend, signify, spell
sens.rel: connote, imply, suggest; add up (to), amount (to); hint, infer, insinuate, intimate; embody, epitomize, personify, represent, symbol, symbolize; advert, allude (to), cite, instance, mention, refer (to), specify, touch (on or upon); designate, indicate, point (to), signal; announce, declare, proclaim; elucidate, explain

sens.vi: your presence at my graduation would mean a lot to me
sens.rel: affect, concern, influence, sway; add up (to), amount (to)

sens.mc: to have in mind as a purpose or goal
sens.vi: I mean to win this race

sens.rel: dream, hope, wish; consider, debate, mull (over), ponder; attempt, endeavor, strive, struggle, try; plot, scheme; accomplish, achieve, effect, execute, perform

sens.mc: to serve as a sign or symptom of
sens.vi: these colder nights mean autumn has truly arrived
sens.syn: bespeak, betoken, denote, mean, point (to), signify, tell (of)

sens.syn: golden mean, medium, middle, middle ground, midpoint
